summary: This is a letter motion filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys, Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, to Judge Alison J. Nathan. Maxwell requests modification of the protective order in her criminal case to allow her to reference and file under seal certain government-produced discovery materials in related civil cases (Giuffre v. Maxwell and a Second Circuit appeal). The motion reveals that the government secretly obtained thousands of pages of sealed civil case materials from the law firm Boies Schiller & Flexner (BSF) via ex parte proceedings, which Maxwell argues undermines the fairness of the civil unsealing process and her due process rights. This document is a legal letter motion filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's attorney, Jeffrey S. Pagliuca, requesting modification of a protective order. Maxwell seeks permission to reference and file under seal certain material in the civil litigation Giuffre v. Maxwell and its related Second Circuit appeal.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) and the subject of the civil defamation case Giuffre v. Maxwell. She is requesting modification of the protective order to use discovery materials in related civil proceedings.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell to whom this letter motion is addressed.

persons.name: Jeffrey Pagliuca
persons.role: Attorney at Haddon, Morgan and Foreman
persons.context: Attorney from the law firm representing Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as the sender of this letter motion.

persons.name: Loretta Preska
persons.context: Judge assigned to handle the unsealing process in the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case after remand from the Second Circuit.

persons.name: Virginia Giuffre
persons.context: She is the plaintiff in the civil litigation 'Giuffre v. Maxwell' referenced in the motion, which is the case where Maxwell seeks to use the material.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the individual whom Giuffre alleged sexually abused and trafficked her, with Maxwell's alleged participation.

persons.name: Jane Doe 43
persons.context: An individual who sued various parties including Maxwell; the case was settled and dismissed. Also represented by Boies Schiller & Flexner (BSF).

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.context: A lawyer from BSF who provided input to Judge Preska during the unsealing process in the Giuffre case.

persons.name: John Doe 1
persons.context: An individual whose deposition transcript was ordered unsealed by Judge Preska along with Maxwell's deposition.

persons.name: Alex Rossmiller
persons.context: A government attorney who provided representations to the court about the use of discovery materials in civil litigation, cited in a letter (Doc. #33).

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: He is the attorney who submitted the letter motion on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell, requesting the court to modify the protective order.

connections.description: The indictment alleges Maxwell 'assisted, facilitated, and contributed' to Epstein's abuse of minors, and Giuffre's civil suit alleged Maxwell participated in a scheme causing her to be sexually abused and trafficked by Epstein.
Giuffre sued Maxwell for defamation in 2015, leading to a civil case with extensive discovery and a protective order. The case settled before trial.
Pagliuca is an attorney at the law firm Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, which is representing Maxwell in her criminal case and filing this motion on her behalf.
BSF represented Giuffre in her civil defamation case against Maxwell. The motion states BSF also represented Jane Doe 43.

The motion alleges BSF cooperated with the government, secretly providing tens of thousands of pages of confidential civil case materials in response to a subpoena, while the unsealing issues were being litigated.
Judge Preska is presiding over the unsealing process in Maxwell's civil case. Maxwell is seeking to inform her about how the government obtained sealed materials.
Jeffrey S. Pagliuca is the attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell, as evidenced by him submitting the legal motion on her behalf.

events.title: Giuffre Files Defamation Lawsuit
events.description: Virginia Giuffre sues Ghislaine Maxwell for defamation, alleging Maxwell defamed her by denying Giuffre's claims of sexual abuse and trafficking by Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Maxwell's First Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell submits to a deposition in the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case, conducted under the protection of a stipulated Protective Order.

events.title: Maxwell's Second Deposition
events.description: Maxwell is compelled to sit for a second deposition in the Giuffre case.

events.title: Settlement of Giuffre Case
events.description: The parties agree to a settlement of the defamation claim days before trial, and the Giuffre v. Maxwell case is dismissed.

events.title: Second Circuit Reverses Unsealing Denial
events.description: The Second Circuit Court of Appeals reverses Judge Sweet's ruling, leading to the unsealing of summary judgment materials in the Giuffre case and remanding for review of remaining records.

events.title: Maxwell Arrested
events.description: The government arrests Ghislaine Maxwell one day after she filed a reply concerning unsealing in the civil matter.

events.title: Superseding Indictment Filed
events.description: The government files a superseding indictment alleging Maxwell assisted in Epstein's abuse of minors and made false statements in her 2016 deposition.

events.title: Judge Preska Orders Unsealing of Depositions
events.description: Judge Loretta Preska orders the unsealing of Maxwell's April 2016 deposition transcript and the transcript of John Doe 1.

events.title: Second Circuit Stays Unsealing Order
events.description: The Second Circuit Court of Appeals stays Judge Preska's order unsealing the deposition transcripts and sets an expedited briefing schedule.

events.title: Government Produces First Discovery Batch
events.description: The government provides the first batch of discovery to Maxwell's New York counsel, including materials related to ex parte proceedings.

events.title: Government Produces BSF Documents
events.description: The government produces approximately 90,000 pages of documents received from Boies Schiller & Flexner, which appear to include their entire civil file from the Giuffre case.

events.title: Filing of Letter Motion to Modify Protective Order
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's attorney files a motion requesting the court to modify a protective order to allow Maxwell to reference and file under seal certain material in the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case and its appeal.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys are seeking court permission to use discovery materials from her criminal case in related civil proceedings, arguing it's necessary for due process and a fair unsealing process.

The motion reveals the U.S. Government secretly obtained tens of thousands of pages of sealed civil case materials from the law firm Boies Schiller & Flexner (BSF) via ex parte proceedings and a subpoena, while public unsealing litigation was ongoing.

Maxwell's attorneys argue that BSF, while representing accusers who may be witnesses in the criminal case, failed to disclose the government's possession of these materials to the courts overseeing the unsealing process.
The government's superseding indictment alleges Maxwell made 'false and perjurious statements' in her 2016 deposition testimony from the Giuffre civil case.

Judge Loretta Preska denied Maxwell's motion to stay the unsealing process because Maxwell could not disclose the 'new information' about the government's possession of materials due to the protective order in the criminal case.
Ghislaine Maxwell's attorney filed a motion to modify a protective order that restricts her from referencing certain material.
The motion seeks to allow Maxwell to refer to and file under seal the material in the civil case Giuffre v. Maxwell (15-cv-5433) and its related Second Circuit appeal (No. 20-2413).
The argument presented is that it is 'illogical and unjust' to prohibit Maxwell from referencing the material since the appellate and district courts are authorized and capable of reviewing it.
The document cites several legal precedents regarding a court's authority to take judicial notice of its own records and proceedings in other courts.
